bookmarks.note: Should a Jew refer to the Pope (e.g. Pope Francis) as ‚ÄúYour Holiness‚Äù? Or maybe (I think) ‚ÄúSir‚Äù?
When kissing hand (if hand extended outward, palm down): slight bow, place lips lightly against skin, press fingers for a second, and allow her to pull her hand away.
When meeting the president, you walk ahead of a woman. Usually, you walk behind a woman
Make a will.
Pay for ballroom dancing lessons. It‚Äôs a wise investment.
Get rudimentary knowledge of at least one foreign language (Russian, French, Mandarin Chinese come to my mind as examples)
Rub flatware, however clean (e.g. if it‚Äôs gone through the dishwasher), with a cloth before setting the table, so it ‚Äútakes on a little shine‚Äù
Here‚Äôs a review of what I need to buy to have in my home. This entire chapter. From towels to spoons
Learn how to sew on a button. Keep a needle and thread in bathroom cabinet and in office desk
On a job interview, dress the way you would during a typical day at the office (figure this out by doing your homework)
Never attempt to make a last-minute date, but don‚Äôt fret to invite someone whose company you enjoy if you happen to get a couple of good  tickets.
Carry breath mints, and offer them to other people when necessary
Put toilet seat down if there‚Äôs a woman there on the premises or a woman will arrive soon. In the morning, always offer to get up and make the coffee.
Don‚Äôt send flowers to a Jewish family that‚Äôs sitting Shiva (why not?)
Listen again for good gift ideas

Buying a gift: shop ahead of time (no last-minute panic). Birthdays (f): flowers, picture frame, new bestseller, dinner or lunch at favorite restaurant. Birthday (m): good whisky or wine, tickets to sports event, drinks at bar or restaurant, bestselling CD. Birthday (Fianc√©e):  flowers, jewelry, family heirloom, framed photo of you too, candlelit dinner. Gifts
for wife: breakfast in bed, dinner at fine restaurant, jewelry, lingerie (only if you know her size and favorite colors). For mother: Sunday lunch or Saturday brunch, tickets to concert.
Woman initiates social kiss. You turn your cheek towards her lips

Dignitary extends hand first, not the gentleman. Same with you don‚Äôt extend a hand to an older person or to a woman. When grabbing the hand of a man: firmly grasp, just BELOW the knuckles. Couple of modest pumps. Immediately release. If woman extends hand, quick, gentle press. Don‚Äôt give a full (regular) up-and-down pump.
Never raise a toast on an empty glass. At least water
Take unchilled wine to a dinner party. Not chilled, so that the host knows that it‚Äôs a gift, and isn‚Äôt intended to accompany dinner
Seat the guest of honor in a good seat: view of the entire room in a banquet hall, or next to host or between two good guests if in a home. In your home, you take the worst seat.
If you invite people who aren‚Äôt well-mannered, just don‚Äôt invite them again.
Don‚Äôt make excuses for other people. Rather [make apologies], ‚ÄúTom, it was so good to see your last night.‚Äù followed by an apology: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry Millicent was so argumentative.‚Äù
If you run low on ice, ask a guest to make an ice run and give him the cash for the ice. Have at least 5 pounds of ice per guest

What to bring with you: Scotch, vodka, gin, white wine, red wine, and bourbon in the south. 
plenty of ice
If red wine will stain your carpet, then you can serve just white.
Serve plenty of mixers.
Invitation: include time, date, location. And what to wear
Goal when entertaining: to put your guests at ease, not to impress them
Damn it. Email isn‚Äôt enough. Follow up with handwritten note.
Prefer email to a phone call if the friend is tied up or grieving.
Simple, handwritten thank you note >= any message left via voicemail
Examples of thank you notes are between this bookmark/note and the previous one. Handwritten note is the only gentlemanly option, no matter how brief. Heartfelt email not good enough.
Never wrong to write a thank you note. Keep it brief and to-the-point. Mention the kindness.

Simple statements are eloquent.
‚ÄúI considered Harold a valuable and trusted friend. I will miss him very much.‚Äù
‚ÄúI know Harold‚Äôs loss is a great blow to you. My thoughts are with you in this difficult time.‚Äù
DON‚ÄôT say, ‚Äúplease let me know if there‚Äôs anything I can do,‚Äù leaving it up to the grieving person to ask for help.
DO offer to supply a meal, run an errand, or watch the house.

How to end a conversation over email: ‚Äúthank you for your help,‚Äù ‚ÄúGood to hear from you, ‚Äúor ‚Äúlet‚Äôs chat again sometime.‚Äú Let that be your ‚Äúfinal contribution to the exchange‚Äù (i.e. don‚Äôt respond to his response).

How to end a conversation in a social situation: ‚Äú it‚Äôs been very pleasant talking with you, Mr. Smith. I‚Äôd like to freshen my drink. Would you care to walk over to the bar along with me?‚Äú If he says yes, then you can now introduce him to other people over at the bar (or on the way over). If he declines, then you can finish it off with, ‚ÄúIt really has been nice chatting with you. I hope we get to talk again soon.‚Äú
How to end a conversation (that you started) in person: stand up, thank your guest for meeting with you, offer/extend your hand for a handshake.
How to end a conversation over the phone: ‚Äúit‚Äôs been very good talking with you, Jack. I hope we get to talk again soon‚Äù
If you started the conversation, then you[‚Äôre the one to] end it

Always introduce a younger person to an older person (‚ÄúMr. older person, I‚Äôd like you to meet Mr./Mrs. younger person), and underling to a boss, a man to a woman (i.e. introduce the person of lower status to the person of higher status, by saying the person-of-higher-status‚Äôs name first).

At a large gathering, don‚Äôt leave yourself standing alone at the edge of the crowd (this will make it harder to reenter the conversation later).

If bar or buffet table, move towards it.

Break the ice with something simple, such as, ‚ÄúMay I step in beside you here in line?‚Äù Or ‚Äúhave you already put in your order?‚Äù
Always begin a conversation by asking a question that does not bring the conversation around to yourself. Also make sure that your keep to positive topics

How to accept a compliment: ‚ÄúThank you, it‚Äôs nice of you to tell me that.‚Äú
Definitely don‚Äôt try to make yourself out to be more, for example, by saying ‚Äúthis old thing‚Äú in a joking manner, because this implies that the person who‚Äôs complimenting you has a questionable taste.

In conversation:

Never ask:
How do the two of you know each other?
Why do I recognize your name?
You don‚Äôt remember me, do you?
Would you mind if I look at the label?
Are you going to eat all of that?

Don‚Äôt brag, whine, or knowingly insult another person. Don‚Äôt revel in others‚Äô embarrassment.
When parking, offer to let the passengers out first
At the dinner table, help the woman to your right as she sits or rises from her chair
After pouring glass of wine, turn bottle slightly, to prevent dribbles and drips

If unsure whether jacket is required, inquire about restaurant‚Äôs dress code ahead of time.
Don‚Äôt talk about a diet if at the table.
If party size changes, inform restaurant.
If restaurant can‚Äôt seat your party, inquire about recommendation of another establishment
Flatware! Right, that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs called (the more general term for silverware).
He says to place your knife and fork ‚Äúside by side as if they were the hands of a clock set at 5:25‚Äù

Don‚Äôt stack your plates at the end of a meal
Also, don‚Äôt cut up all the food at the beginning [i.e. cut a little at a time]
Slip host/maitre d‚Äô $20+ as you‚Äôre preparing to leave (if they are basically a waiter in an upscale restaurant‚Äîif medium scale, then maitre d only seats you, then no need to tip him)

upscale restaurant: entr√©e >= $30
Tip wine steward 20% of cost of wine
Never wear the same pair of jeans twice in a row

Take off a hat in a place of worship (not! He‚Äôs wrong here. Maybe in a church, but I don‚Äôt walk into a church), upon entering a doctor or lawyer‚Äôs office (not in the waiting room/lobby/vestibule), and when speaking with a person such as a teller. Tip the hat if covering matted hair or a bald spot or take it off when greeting someone new or speaking with a woman. And at an indoor meal

‚ÄúMemorial Day‚Äù = Summer cut-off. When he talks about before and after memorial day, he‚Äôs referring to before and after the start of the dog days of summer. Socks not necessary after summer starts
Socks complement trousers (not shoes?). Like Mom mentioned about the blue socks that would go well with jeans
Always wear gloves, so your handshake isn‚Äôt cold
Let suit jacket
Know where to find a high-quality dry cleaner. Take your clothes there as seldom as possible, as chemicals shorten the lifespan of clothes
Cologne: dab on either side of the neck is enough
No bulky stuff in pockets
Clip nose hair. invest  in a trimmer for it
‚ÄúNo cowboy boots with a suit‚Äù [i.e. make sure your shoes match your attire?]
Wear an undershirt in warm weather
If answering ‚Äúyes,‚Äù never reply all. Only send a message to everyone if it pertains to everyone
When expressing gratitude, use a handwritten note or a voice-to-voice phone call
Try to capture your tone in your email message
‚ÄúMay I please speak with an English-speaking supervisor?‚Äù
Change bedsheets after eating or every two weeks
‚ÄúThe chaise has been empty for so long, I simply folded your towels and set them here. I hope I kept them in good order.‚Äù
Don‚Äôt wear Black Tie attire before 5 p.m.
At wedding, side of bride = left, side of groom = right. If you know them both, then sit on the side with more empty seats
‚ÄúScreen‚Äù your calls. (What does this mean/entail? Does this mean you ask who‚Äôs calling forthwith, or does it mean you have someone answer your calls for you?)
When entering a row, face the other people in the mail.  In other words, face towards them, away from the stage
If you have a tendency to cough, carry around a mint or throat lozenge
